p: As noted earlier in this paper, the open structure of the closo-boranes (B nH n −) results in increased ionic conduction over the nido- BH 4 − units. In fact, closo-boranes realize ionic conductivities, which are five orders of magnitude higher than nido- structures. Other work has shown that rapid cationic conduction (3 × 10 −2 S/cm) occurs in the LiB 10H 10 and NaB 10H 10 phases [ 10, 12]. Similarly, rapid ionic conduction is observed for the -B 12H 12 closo-borane phases [ 10, 11, 12, 20, 24]. Because of their high ionic conductivities, ease of synthesis and safety of use, for the closo-boranes should also be considered. The closo-boranes (B nH n −) could readily be synthesized following the resin-based ion exchange methods as described in the thesis by Blake [ 43], beginning with commercial triethanolamine (TEAH)-B nH n purchased from Boron Specialties, LLC. Some borohydrides, such as borane, diborane, and pentaborane, are known to be toxic and pose environmental safety hazards and so safe handling must be considered. These are primarily in stoichiometries x < 5 in B xH y (e.g., BH 3, B 2H 6, or B 5H 9) and are liquid or gaseous at room temperature, toxic, and highly reactive with oxygen in air.
